news_summary: Today's environmental news highlights advancements in understanding natural adaptations, rapid progress in renewable energy development, and the urgent impact of deforestation on extreme weather events.
news_summary_fr: L'actualité environnementale d'aujourd'hui met en lumière les avancées dans la compréhension des adaptations naturelles, les progrès rapides dans le développement des énergies renouvelables et l'impact urgent de la déforestation sur les phénomènes météorologiques extrêmes.
news_summary_es: Las noticias medioambientales de hoy destacan los avances en la comprensión de las adaptaciones naturales, el rápido progreso en el desarrollo de energías renovables y el urgente impacto de la deforestación en los fenómenos meteorológicos extremos.

articles.title: How the world’s biggest bats got their enormous wingspans
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 17 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02228-zGenetic analysis helps to reveal why flying foxes can measure almost 2 metres from wingtip to wingtip.
articles.content: Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in Internet Explorer). In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles and JavaScript.
articles.reasoning: The article discusses scientific research that reveals genetic reasons behind the large wingspans of flying foxes, which contributes to our understanding of biodiversity and animal biology. This kind of scientific insight supports conservation awareness and appreciation of wildlife.
articles.personality_title: How flying foxes got their giant wingspans
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Flying foxes are the world’s largest bats, with wings that can stretch nearly two meters from tip to tip. Scientists have long been curious about what makes their wings so impressively big.

**What happened**
Recent research used genetic analysis to uncover the reasons behind flying foxes’ enormous wingspans. By studying their DNA, scientists found specific genes that help these bats grow such large wings.

**Impact**
This discovery boosts our understanding of animal biology and biodiversity. Knowing the genetic factors that shape these bats helps us appreciate their unique traits and highlights the importance of protecting them and their habitats.

**What's next step**
Researchers plan to explore how these genes work and whether they can help explain wing growth in other animals. This could open doors to new conservation strategies and deepen our knowledge of evolution.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Scientists have unlocked genetic clues explaining why flying foxes have the world’s biggest bat wings, helping us better appreciate and protect these amazing creatures.
articles.personality_title_fr: Comment les renards volants ont obtenu leurs immenses envergures
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les renards volants sont les plus grands chauves-souris du monde, avec des ailes pouvant atteindre près de deux mètres d’un bout à l’autre. Les scientifiques se sont longtemps demandé pourquoi leurs ailes sont si grandes.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Une récente recherche utilisant l’analyse génétique a révélé les raisons derrière l’immense envergure des renards volants. En étudiant leur ADN, les chercheurs ont identifié des gènes spécifiques qui aident ces chauves-souris à développer de grandes ailes.

**Impact**
Cette découverte améliore notre compréhension de la biologie animale et de la biodiversité. Connaître les facteurs génétiques qui façonnent ces chauves-souris nous aide à mieux apprécier leurs caractéristiques uniques et souligne l’importance de les protéger ainsi que leurs habitats.

**Prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs prévoient d’étudier comment ces gènes fonctionnent et s’ils peuvent expliquer la croissance des ailes chez d’autres animaux. Cela pourrait ouvrir la voie à de nouvelles stratégies de conservation et approfondir notre compréhension de l’évolution.

**Résumé en une phrase**
Les scientifiques ont découvert des indices génétiques expliquant pourquoi les renards volants ont les plus grandes ailes de chauves-souris au monde, ce qui nous aide à mieux apprécier et protéger ces créatures extraordinaires.
articles.personality_title_es: Cómo los zorros voladores consiguieron sus gigantescas envergaduras
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Los zorros voladores son los murciélagos más grandes del mundo, con alas que pueden medir casi dos metros de punta a punta. Los científicos siempre han querido saber por qué sus alas son tan grandes.

**Qué pasó**
Una investigación reciente utilizó análisis genético para descubrir las razones detrás de las enormes envergaduras de los zorros voladores. Al estudiar su ADN, los científicos encontraron genes específicos que ayudan a estos murciélagos a crecer alas tan grandes.

**Impacto**
Este descubrimiento mejora nuestra comprensión de la biología animal y la biodiversidad. Conocer los factores genéticos que forman a estos murciélagos nos ayuda a apreciar mejor sus rasgos únicos y destaca la importancia de protegerlos a ellos y a sus hábitats.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores planean estudiar cómo funcionan estos genes y si pueden ayudar a explicar el crecimiento de alas en otros animales. Esto podría abrir nuevas vías para estrategias de conservación y profundizar nuestro conocimiento sobre la evolución.

**Resumen en una frase**
Los científicos han descubierto pistas genéticas que explican por qué los zorros voladores tienen las alas más grandes del mundo, ayudándonos a apreciar y proteger mejor a estas increíbles criaturas.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a majestic giant fruit bat with its enormous, outstretched wings spanning wide above a calm tropical forest at dusk, rendered in soft natural browns, muted grays, and gentle greens, emphasizing the bat’s impressive wingspan and graceful flight without any human figures.

articles.title: The race to build solar and wind in New York before Trump’s tax credit deadline
articles.content:
As negotiations over President Donald Trump’s “Big Beautiful Bill” came down to the wire in early July, renewable energy developers were holding their breath. Until the eleventh hour, it looked like Congress was ready to make good on Trump’s promise of “terminating” key subsidies for wind and solar virtually overnight.

In the end, the industry breathed a small sigh of relief after the Senate reached a compromise that would, at least in principle, give new projects a slim window to go ahead. Under the final law, wind and solar projects that begin construction by July 4 of next year are eligible for the full federal tax credits. Halfway through that window, a new requirement kicks in: Projects that begin construction after January 1, 2026, can only keep the tax credits if they follow restrictions on the use of Chinese materials.

That could still upend New York’s renewable energy transition.

Federal tax credits have typically covered almost a third of the cost of building a solar or wind farm. That’s made them “critical to financing and ultimately building renewable energy projects,” said Carl Weatherley-White, interim chief financial officer at the development firm Greenbacker, which is currently building New York’s largest solar farm and has several smaller projects in the works. “It’s been a core part of the business for 20 years.”

To support our nonprofit environmental journalism, please consider disabling your ad-blocker to allow ads on Grist. Here's How

The bill will also impact New York’s public power authority, NYPA, which this year issued a plan to put up more than three gigawatts’ worth of solar and batteries, and has been counting on federal tax credits to deliver.

Developers now have less than a year to start digging if they want the subsidies. The impending deadline is lighting a fire under the industry — and, developers hope, under New York’s leaders, too.

“Now, the game is in the states,” said Marguerite Wells, executive director of the renewable energy lobbying group Alliance for Clean Energy New York. “I would say there’s many thousands of megawatts’ worth of wind and solar in upstate that would be eligible to fall into that start of construction if we played the cards right.”

For a start, there are 26 permitted but unbuilt wind and solar projects in the state, which in total could unlock about 3,000 megawatts’ worth of energy — enough to power some half a million homes. Only two of the large projects the state has approved in the last four years have even started construction; one of them was completed in late 2024, more than six years after filing its first paperwork. (The most recent permit was issued last week, but most of the permits date back to 2023 or earlier.)

To support our nonprofit environmental journalism, please consider disabling your ad-blocker to allow ads on Grist. Here's How

The problem? The state doesn’t make it easy to move quickly. It normally takes years for wind and solar projects just to get permits to begin construction in New York, despite reforms intended to speed up the process. The rest of the approval process can take years, too. More environmental reviews are required even after the main permit is approved. And it’s just as complicated getting approval to connect to the grid.

All told, at least three different sets of regulators have to weigh in before a company can put shovels in the ground. That makes New York far more restrictive than other states in allowing developers to start building.

There are things the state could do to speed things up, like allowing developers to start construction even while they finalize certain details of their projects, but it’s largely in Governor Kathy Hochul’s hands.

Jolting the process forward would require a concerted push across her agencies. Besides permits, building a wind or solar farm in New York requires a contract with the state’s energy research and development arm, NYSERDA, guaranteeing that the developer will get paid for the energy the facility produces. Sometimes it requires the state Department of Environmental Conservation to weigh in on water quality plans, with additional input from the US Army Corps of Engineers. And it requires the state’s grid operator — which acts independently — to assess the impact and cost of connecting the facility to the grid.

Developers need answers from all of those entities before they can break ground, Wells said: “Every last whisper of detail of the project has to be finalized before they generally let you start construction.”

In her eyes, improving coordination between all of New York’s energy regulators is the single biggest thing the state could do to help move construction forward.

It’s not yet clear how committed Hochul is to the effort.

“The Governor has directed the state’s energy agencies to conduct a high-level review of the federal legislation and specific impacts to New Yorkers,” spokesperson Ken Lovett told New York Focus, when asked whether the Hochul administration shared developers’ goal of accelerating construction.

Greenbacker’s 20-megawatt “Albany 1” solar project, in Albany County, New York. Courtesy of Greenbacker Renewable Energy Company

Before most developers even had a chance to fully digest the changes coming down from Congress, Trump threw in another gut punch. Last week, he issued an executive order directing the Treasury Department, which enforces tax credit rules, to revisit how it defines a project’s “start of construction.”

That throws even the megabill’s one-year deadline into doubt. Historically, developers have been allowed to qualify for tax credits by proving either that they’ve started physical construction or spent a certain amount of money. Now, Trump has given federal regulators 45 days to revise those definitions.

The specific definitions that the Treasury adopts could prove decisive in some cases. But whatever exact language the administration lands on, the bottom line is that Trump still has significant leeway to kill wind and solar projects if he’s committed to it, said Advait Arun, senior associate for energy finance at the think tank Center for Public Enterprise.

“Simply, I think Trump is trying to use control over the IRS to exercise his judgment about what projects should proceed and what shouldn’t,” he said.

Trump will have even more sway after the end of this calendar year, when additional requirements kick in. Starting in January 2026, developers hoping to claim tax credits will have to abide by restrictions on sourcing from “Foreign Entities of Concern,” including those connected to the Chinese government. The megabill tasks the Treasury with updating those rules, giving Trump another opportunity to crack down on what he’s called the “Green New Scam.”

It all adds up to shaky terrain for renewable developers, even those who stand a chance of getting shovels in the ground within a year.

“The big concern … is that no matter what we do, someone in the Treasury is going to just say no,” said Weatherley-White, of Greenbacker, speaking to New York Focus a few hours before Trump issued his executive order last week. (Reporting earlier this month had already suggested that the construction rules could be in the crosshairs.)

Neither Weatherley-White nor Wells, of ACE NY, responded to follow-up inquiries about the order.

Unless the Trump administration completely upends what counts as the “start of construction,” there’s still a lot New York could do to help more projects get in under the one-year bar.

For example, in many states, wind and solar developers can begin construction on projects that don’t have all of their final approvals, but have the main elements of their design — like the location of roads and buildings — agreed upon, Wells said. But in New York, that initial green light is hard to get. It would make a big difference if the state were to adopt the practice more readily, she said.

New York could also jumpstart the contracting process for wind and solar projects. Close to half of the state’s permitted but unbuilt projects had contracts that were canceled after post-pandemic inflation upended their finances. Over the last year, the state has announced new contracts for dozens of projects in this situation, but others remain in limbo.

NYSERDA had plans to kick off a fresh round of wind and solar contracting by the end of June, but it’s behind schedule. A spokesperson said the agency would begin the process by the end of September.

Those nitty-gritty steps are unlikely to change, though, unless Hochul makes it a priority. The governor could direct agencies to fast track permitting or contracts, as she did with offshore wind a couple of years ago. She has lately shown a keen interest in cutting red tape for other forms of energy — specifically, a nuclear plant that she has tasked NYPA to build by 2040. (There, though, the key approvals need to come from the Trump administration rather than her own.)

Her Department of Environmental Conservation also appears to be speeding along a revived pipeline project that would bring gas into New York City and Long Island. The agency said earlier this month that it had received a complete application from the pipeline company and opened a 30-day comment period with no public hearing. The notice came just five weeks after it was revealed that the state would reconsider the previously abandoned project — reportedly as part of a deal with the Trump administration to allow a major offshore wind project to move ahead, though Hochul’s office has denied a quid pro quo.

Renewable developers, by contrast, can spend years applying and reapplying for permits before they’re allowed to proceed to a mandatory, 60-day public comment period.

“If we’re cutting red tape for other forms of energy, we should cut red tape for renewable energy, too,” Wells said.

Whether any wind or solar projects remain viable in New York after the federal tax credits expire remains an open question. Although Trump has framed his efforts as rolling back Biden-era policies, solar and wind tax credits date as far back as the 1970s, and have remained largely steady since 2005.

Some, like Weatherley-White, remain optimistic that the renewable industry can learn to live without them.

“The renewable energy industry has adapted to lots of changes over time,” he said, suggesting that developers could find ways to cut costs to cushion the blow from losing the tax credits.

“Unfortunately, there will be losers and winners,” Weatherley-White continued. “I think we’re going to see some short-term pain. But in the long run or medium term, let’s say, I think people will adapt and succeed.”

The labor coalition Climate Jobs NY struck a similarly bullish tone in a statement earlier this month. “With or without the support from our federal lawmakers, union workers in New York will find ways to build the pro-worker clean energy economy we need,” the group wrote.

Others see the glass half empty. Arun said that a key part of how the industry hoped to bring down costs was by using tax credits to build momentum and standardize the development process.

“If you can’t build, there’s no standardization or lowering costs through economies of scale,” he said. “And that’s what I’m really worried about.”

Hochul’s office, too, is striking a sober note.

“The federal budget bill slashes the very tools states need to achieve energy independence and economic growth,” Lovett said, “and no state will be able to backfill the massive cuts they face across so many key areas.”
articles.reasoning: The article discusses the challenges and opportunities in advancing renewable energy projects in New York, highlighting efforts to build solar and wind farms before federal tax credits expire. Despite political and bureaucratic hurdles, there is optimism about the renewable energy industry's adaptability and potential for growth, which aligns with environmental progress and sustainability goals.
articles.personality_title: New York pushes ahead with solar and wind projects before tax credits expire
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
In early July, the future of key federal subsidies for solar and wind energy was uncertain as Congress debated President Trump’s plan to end these tax credits. These subsidies help make clean energy projects affordable and appealing to developers.

**What happened**
At the last moment, the Senate reached a compromise that allows new solar and wind projects in New York a small window to move forward before the tax credits disappear. This gave renewable energy developers a much-needed boost to continue their work.

**Impact**
Thanks to this compromise, New York is speeding up efforts to build more solar and wind farms. These projects not only create jobs but also support the state’s clean energy goals and reduce pollution, helping communities and the environment.

**What’s next step**
Developers in New York will work quickly to start new renewable projects while tax credits are still available. The state will likely continue pushing policies to encourage clean energy growth and adapt to any future changes in federal support.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A last-minute deal gives New York’s solar and wind industries a crucial boost, keeping clean energy progress on track just in time.
articles.personality_title_fr: New York accélère les projets solaires et éoliens avant la fin des crédits d'impôt
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Début juillet, l’avenir des subventions fédérales pour l’énergie solaire et éolienne était incertain, alors que le Congrès discutait du plan du président Trump pour mettre fin à ces crédits d’impôt. Ces aides rendent les projets d’énergie propre plus abordables et attractifs pour les développeurs.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
À la dernière minute, le Sénat a trouvé un compromis qui permet aux nouveaux projets solaires et éoliens à New York de démarrer dans une courte période avant la disparition des crédits d’impôt. Cela a apporté un nouveau souffle aux développeurs d’énergie renouvelable.

**Impact**
Grâce à ce compromis, New York accélère la construction de fermes solaires et éoliennes. Ces projets créent des emplois, soutiennent les objectifs de l’État en matière d’énergie propre et réduisent la pollution, au bénéfice des communautés et de l’environnement.

**Prochaine étape**
Les développeurs à New York vont rapidement lancer de nouveaux projets renouvelables tant que les crédits d’impôt sont encore disponibles. L’État continuera probablement à encourager la croissance de l’énergie propre et à s’adapter aux évolutions futures du soutien fédéral.

**En une phrase**
Un accord de dernière minute offre un coup de pouce crucial aux industries solaires et éoliennes de New York, maintenant le progrès de l’énergie propre en bonne voie juste à temps.
articles.personality_title_es: Nueva York impulsa proyectos solares y eólicos antes de que finalicen los créditos fiscales
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
A principios de julio, el futuro de los subsidios federales clave para la energía solar y eólica era incierto mientras el Congreso debatía el plan del presidente Trump de terminar con estos créditos fiscales. Estos subsidios hacen que los proyectos de energía limpia sean más asequibles y atractivos para los desarrolladores.

**Qué pasó**
En el último momento, el Senado llegó a un compromiso que permite que nuevos proyectos solares y eólicos en Nueva York avancen en una pequeña ventana antes de que desaparezcan los créditos fiscales. Esto dio un impulso importante a los desarrolladores de energía renovable.

**Impacto**
Gracias a este compromiso, Nueva York está acelerando la construcción de más parques solares y eólicos. Estos proyectos no solo crean empleos, sino que también apoyan las metas estatales de energía limpia y reducen la contaminación, beneficiando a las comunidades y al medio ambiente.

**Próximo paso**
Los desarrolladores en Nueva York trabajarán rápidamente para comenzar nuevos proyectos renovables mientras los créditos fiscales aún estén disponibles. Es probable que el estado continúe promoviendo políticas para fomentar el crecimiento de la energía limpia y adaptarse a futuros cambios en el apoyo federal.

**Resumen en una frase**
Un acuerdo de último momento brinda un impulso crucial a las industrias solar y eólica de Nueva York, manteniendo el progreso de la energía limpia justo a tiempo.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a vibrant New York landscape featuring large solar panels and elegant wind turbines rising on gentle rolling hills under a soft sky, with golden light illuminating a clock face subtly integrated into the background symbolizing a ticking deadline, and a network of interconnected pathways representing complex regulatory processes winding through the scene.

articles.title: 18x more floods, 105% bigger storms — all from a single clear-cut
articles.summary: Clear-cutting forests doesn’t just raise flood risk — it can supercharge it. UBC researchers found that in certain watersheds, floods became up to 18 times more frequent and over twice as severe after clear-cutting, with these effects lasting more than four decades. The surprise? Terrain details like which direction a slope faces played a huge role in flood behavior. Conventional models miss these dynamics, which could mean we've been underestimating the danger for decades — especially as climate change accelerates extreme weather.
articles.content:
Clear-cutting can make catastrophic floods 18 times more frequent with effects lasting more than 40 years, according to a new UBC study.

In one watershed, these extreme floods also became more than twice as large, turning a once-in-70-years event into something that now happens every nine.

"This research challenges conventional thinking about forest management's impact on flooding," said senior author Dr. Younes Alila, a hydrologist in the UBC faculty of forestry. "We hope the industry and policymakers will take note of the findings, which show that it matters not only how much forest you remove but also where, how and under what conditions."

Same treatment, different floods

The UBC-led study draws on one of the world's longest-running forest experiments at the Coweeta Hydrologic Laboratory in North Carolina and is published in the Journal of Hydrology.

The research team analyzed two adjacent watersheds, one north-facing, the other south-facing, that were both clear-cut in the late 1950s.

"We found seemingly minor landscape factors -- like the direction a slope faces -- can make or break a watershed's response to treatment," said first author Henry Pham, a doctoral student in the faculty of forestry.

In the north-facing watershed, which receives less direct sunlight and retains more moisture, floods became four to 18 times more frequent. Average flood sizes increased by 47 percent compared to pre-treatment levels, and the biggest floods grew by as much as 105 percent.

In the south-facing watershed, the same treatment had virtually no impact on flood behavior.

Old flood models inadequate

Most conventional flood models use simplified assumptions: cut X percent of trees, expect Y percent more water runoff. But this study found that such models fail to account for extreme and erratic flood patterns that emerge after landscape disturbances.

"This experimental evidence validates our longstanding call for better analysis methods," said Dr. Alila. "When we apply proper probabilistic tools to long-term data, we find much stronger and more variable impacts than older models suggest."

In short, he adds, forest treatments don't just raise average flood levels -- they can fundamentally reshape a watershed's entire flood regime, making rare and catastrophic events much more common.

The most concerning finding was that flood effects in the north-facing watershed persisted for over 40 years, confirming that forestry treatments can lead to long-term changes in a watershed's flood response, especially as climate change brings more extreme weather, putting downstream communities at greater risk.

Policy implications

The findings have immediate relevance for forest management practices, particularly in B.C. where there are similar terrain types and forestry operations in the form of clear-cut logging.

Dr. Alila noted that the model used in this study can be used to predict which parts of B.C. are currently more at risk of extreme flooding. It can also be used to investigate how much of the severity of Sumas Prairie floods in 2021 and the more recent Texas floods can be attributed to global warming and/or land use and forest cover changes.

"Our findings highlight how multiple landscape factors interact in complex ways. As climate conditions shift, understanding those dynamics is becoming increasingly important for forest and water management."
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a significant scientific breakthrough in understanding the long-term impacts of clear-cutting on flood risk, which has important implications for forest management and flood prevention policies. While the findings reveal concerning environmental risks, the research provides valuable knowledge that can lead to better protection of communities and ecosystems, making it hopeful and constructive.
articles.personality_title: Clear-cutting forests can cause floods 18 times more often and twice as big — here’s what we learned
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
A study from the University of British Columbia looked at how clear-cutting, which means cutting down all trees in an area, affects flooding. Floods are growing worse with climate change, so understanding what makes them worse is important.

**What happened**
Researchers found that after clear-cutting in some river areas, floods happened up to 18 times more often and the biggest floods were more than twice as large. These effects lasted for more than 40 years. They also discovered that the way land slopes and which direction it faces changes how floods behave—something normal flood models miss.

**Impact**
This research shows that cutting down forests can dramatically increase flood risks for decades. Knowing this helps communities and forest managers better protect land and people from floods, especially as extreme weather events become more common.

**What's next step**
The next step is to update forest management and flood prediction methods to include these new findings. By considering how terrain influences flooding and limiting clear-cutting in sensitive areas, we can reduce future flood damage.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Cutting down forests without care can greatly increase flood risks for decades, but new research gives us clear clues to better protect our communities and environment.
articles.personality_title_fr: La coupe à blanc des forêts peut multiplier les inondations par 18 et doubler leur taille — voici ce que nous avons appris
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Une étude de l'Université de la Colombie-Britannique a examiné comment la coupe à blanc, c’est-à-dire l’abattage de tous les arbres d’une zone, affecte les inondations. Les inondations s’aggravent avec le changement climatique, il est donc important de comprendre ce qui les amplifie.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Les chercheurs ont découvert qu’après une coupe à blanc dans certains bassins versants, les inondations se produisaient jusqu’à 18 fois plus souvent et que les inondations les plus importantes étaient plus de deux fois plus grandes. Ces effets duraient plus de 40 ans. Ils ont aussi remarqué que la pente du terrain et son exposition influençaient le comportement des inondations, un facteur ignoré par les modèles habituels.

**Impact**
Cette recherche montre que couper les forêts peut augmenter fortement les risques d’inondation pendant des décennies. Cette connaissance aide les communautés et gestionnaires forestiers à mieux protéger les terres et les personnes, surtout avec la fréquence croissante des événements météo extrêmes.

**Prochaine étape**
Il faut maintenant mettre à jour les méthodes de gestion forestière et de prévision des inondations en intégrant ces nouvelles découvertes. En tenant compte du terrain et en limitant la coupe à blanc dans les zones sensibles, on peut réduire les dégâts futurs.

**Conclusion en une phrase**
Couper les forêts sans précaution peut fortement augmenter les risques d’inondation pendant des décennies, mais cette recherche apporte des pistes claires pour mieux protéger nos communautés et notre environnement.
articles.personality_title_es: La tala rasa de bosques puede causar inundaciones 18 veces más frecuentes y el doble de grandes — esto es lo que aprendimos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Un estudio de la Universidad de Columbia Británica analizó cómo la tala rasa, que significa cortar todos los árboles de una zona, afecta las inundaciones. Las inundaciones empeoran con el cambio climático, por lo que entender qué las agrava es importante.

**Qué pasó**
Los investigadores descubrieron que después de la tala rasa en algunas cuencas, las inundaciones ocurrieron hasta 18 veces más seguido y las más grandes fueron más del doble de grandes. Estos efectos duraron más de 40 años. También hallaron que la inclinación y orientación del terreno cambian cómo se comportan las inundaciones—algo que los modelos normales no consideran.

**Impacto**
Esta investigación muestra que talar bosques puede aumentar mucho el riesgo de inundaciones por décadas. Con esta información, las comunidades y gestores forestales pueden proteger mejor la tierra y a las personas, especialmente con eventos climáticos extremos más comunes.

**Próximo paso**
El siguiente paso es actualizar la gestión forestal y los métodos de predicción de inundaciones para incluir estos descubrimientos. Considerando cómo el terreno influye y limitando la tala rasa en áreas sensibles, podemos reducir daños futuros.

**Conclusión en una frase**
Cortar bosques sin cuidado puede aumentar mucho el riesgo de inundaciones por décadas, pero esta nueva investigación nos da claves claras para proteger mejor a nuestras comunidades y el medio ambiente.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of two adjacent forested watersheds on gentle slopes—one north-facing lush and moist with a vibrant river overflowing into a wide floodplain, the other south-facing drier with a calm, contained stream—highlighting contrasting flood behaviors through flowing water patterns and subtle landscape textures, using natural earthy greens, blues, and browns in soft, inviting tones.
